reviewText:
At its peak, this was one of my favorite games of all time, the combat mechanics were deep and had a steep learning curve, the armor system was very complex and logical, and above all this game rewarded the skill of the players.

Of the 140 hours I've played, roughly 100 of them were spent on dueling servers fighting 1on1 with other players, all of whom were there because they enjoyed the actual competition or to master their skills with a new weapon. The dueling community was strong and friendly, always willing to help teach new players how to survive the game.

But then the Devs changed things, the armor system simplified, the weapons became more powerful, crossbows became sniper rifles, hitboxes and crit chances grew, and the art of dueling was lost to the ether; replaced by polearm decapitations, across the map crossbow headshots, and stab spamming. All that is left now is the empty rotting shell of a once great game.

reviewText:
Warning! Paradox has stopped all further development on War of the Roses officially, there will be no further updates or support. No more content, bugfixes or balancing.

Look it up here:
http://forum.paradoxplaza.com/forum/showthread.php?803910-Statement-regarding-the-War-franchise&s=37a86469bf953fa83a2843f2964171c7

War of the Roses has come a long way, or rather suffered a very steep downfall.

At its launch in 2012 War of the Roses was definitely the best Mount&Blade-like experience one could hope for. The game was exciting: brutally challenging, but very fair and nicely balanced. This was a game for core-players with a quite steep but very rewarding learning curve and skill-ceiling. The (old) armor-system was very complex and good implemented in the overall gameplay mechanics: Deflecting & glancing blows were common, and it was hard to overcome plate armor with simple sword-blades. One had to use his wits and skills when fighting opponents without a suitable weapon to counter their loadout-choices.

This made the game very enjoyable at the early launch-state.

But all of this is not the case anymore, the game has gravely decreased in quality and is nothing more than a rotting patchwork, leaking players every week.

The countless misdirected balance patches and simplifications of game mechanics were painful to witness.
Rather than addressing the ever swelling balance problems and bugs - the development team decided to flood the game with mostly unbalanced and unwanted content, which only derailed the game even more. The removal of the complex armor system and the enhancement of hitbox-sizes were very poor moves. Fatshark tried to stabilize the playerbase by lowering the skill curve, but this only backfired even more.

This game still suffers from fatal bugs and exploits - which have been very well documented and reported by the community since launch.
The network-performance of the game is horrible and was never addressed by the developer, and due to the iron grip of the Multiplay monopoly the actual server coverage and quality is very poor.

I personally stopped playing WotR after trying to help the game back to its old glory by participating in balance-betas and writing extensive feedback & bug reports. Sadly the game did never improve in quality. The last patch (which was yet again very disappointing) was months ago. Fatshark & Paradox abandoned the game.

It makes me quite sad to say it, as this game was once so great - but no, don't waste your money on this game.

As the 1000+ hours demonstrate this has been my favourite game for quite some time now. Unfortunately, due to mismanagement, missing anti-cheat, totalitarian attitudes towards players on the forums, and glitches and bugs that just never get fixed, the player-base is falling!

In detail

Mismanagement: Promises were and have been made and NEVER fulfilled. These include a single-player mode, leader boards, and monthly content updates that were there for a while but now it’s not even one in half a year.

Missing anti-cheat: The servers are full with cheaters and despite promises of bans and account wipes from Paradox, nothing has been done. An anti-cheat system was announces last year and was stated to be coming “soon”... it is now June the following year and there is nothing. Most people leaving the game say this is the reason.

Totalitarian attitudes towards players on the forums: The game had an amazing community forum right from Alpha. Players got to know each other on and off the battlefield and some fantastic discussions were had on balance, new content, and tournaments. Unfortunately, once the community started to complain about broken promises and bad game experiences, the Mods started banning and infracting left right and centre. Prizes were promised for tournaments but were not given or only given after months of nagging by the organisers...

Glitches and bugs: Some bugs were reported during Alpha and never fixed. The worst part is that many bugs were reported and fixed in a patch, only to reappear with the next patch.

Summary: The game started off in Beta offering around 60% of what the Publishers were promising, which was an amazing start. Players loved it and it held an average daily player list of around 2000 players for months. It peaked at maybe 70% and then with the introduction of the Kingmaker patch it started to fall and has since fallen into an abyss of laggy servers, bad netcode, cheaters, OP-builds and weapons, a server browser that doesn’t work, leader boards that  don’t work, and a publisher who keeps promising and promising but who never does anything.

My loyalty to the game drives me to recommend it, but right now I just can’t.

WOTR is a great game with a great combat system.
The melee combat system works with directional swings and stabs, the way you move your mouse when you hold the LMB will determine where you will swing from (e.g. if you hold LMB and move the mouse to the left, you will pull your weapon back the left side and swing to the right). Not to mention you have to compensate for what kind of weapon you have compaired to the enemies armour. This makes for very strategic placement of swings and stabs and very intence battles/duels.

In War of the Roses you can make your own loadout of weapons, from the devistating (aka OverPowered) Pollaxe to the all mighty Quarterstaff. After playing a while and you learn how to play the game properly, you tend to (Alot of the time accidentally) create and learn your own style of fighting and when you make your loadout, you will feel like this character really is YOUR personal character.

Personally I find it really fun when you are playing with a group of people and you make a shield wall, do a calvary charge, hail the enemy with arrows or even just duel eachother one on one.

Overall, I highly reccomend you try the free demo of this game to see if it is the right game for you.

reviewText:
Overview
This game has two fighting mechanics:
Melee and ranged. This is playing a central role in the game, because you can setup your own class.
You can basically do everything. You can choose perks for your soldier. You can also choose which weapon (main weapon and sidearm) and which dagger. When you choose a weapon, you can also decide which fighting style you'd like to have. For example you can choose between Imperial or Milanese  fighting style. You can choose between many different armor types. There are light armors and heavy armors. If you want you can also ride a horse and play with lance. Shields are available as well.

Melee
Melee is much more complicated than ranged. While attacking you can choose between four directions. You can hit from the left and right side. You can also perform overhead swings and you can stab your opponent. Same for parrying your opponents attack! To attack you press the left mouse button and move your mouse to the attacking direction. To parry you press the right mouse button and move your mouse to the direction you want to parry.
Parrying with shields is a lot easier! You basically have to press your right mouse button and it blocks to all four directions.
But shields make you heavier and slower. And shield can also break. You have to decide carefully how you set up your own class!

Ranged
While you play melee in the Third-Person Perspective ranged is in the First-Person
If you want to play ranged you can choose between three different ranged weapons:
• Bow
You can choose which bow you'd like to take and you can choose the arrow. Compared to the crossbow the bow is faster but performs less damage.
• Crossbow
You can choose between different crossbows and arrows. Crossbows have a longer reload time than bows. If you aim carefully you can perform a lot of damage!
• Handgonne
The handgonne is a little bit different. You take your handgonne and shoot once. Then you switch to melee and have to wait for the handgonne to magically reload ;)

The in-game currency
To create your own class you have to earn in-game gold. If your new it might be a bit hard to earn a lot of gold. But the most weapons, shields, armors and helmets are cheap. Only the exclusive stuff is expensive: For example special looking weapons or colours for your armors. If you want you can also pay real money to get in game gold. But this is not necessary.

Conclusion
War of the Roses is a lot of fun because you can choose almost everything for your own soldier.
The game's biggest problems are the balance issues. Some weapons are stronger than others.

First things first, I applaud the makers of this game for exploring a historical period rarely (perhaps never?) touched on in gaming history. Truly, I enjoyed my time running around the English countryside. The countryside, while not exactly Crysis-level graphics porn, is still wonderfully rendered.

Now, let's move into the less flattering aspects of this game. The first problem I noticed about this game is the controls. Now you still move around with the WASD keys, so that's pretty standard. But to swing your weapon around, you would click on your mouse and move it to decide the direction of your swing. This is awkward because your mouse also controls your view, so swinging your weapon around means your view will be swinging around as well. Now you may point out that I can always play as an archer, but what's the point of playing this game then? If you're unsure if this is a game for you, play the trial (that's the free version on Steam) first. If it makes you dizzy, then this is definitely not the game for you.

The second problem is the balance of this game. It's not difficult to find a random dude lobbing everyone's head off with the Peasant Polearm (it's a rake...). Even if it doesn't result in an insta-kill, it still deals a heavy dose of damage. The swing speed is much faster than any axe. Seriously, what's up with that? If that didn't convince you, let me point out that the Longbow cannot kill a player at full health with an arrow to the face, regardless of range. If that still didn't convince you, then may you be killed by dudes dressed in rags. These guys can takedown a heavily armoured knight with their speed.

Eleven months (at the time of writing this review) after release, bugs and exploits are still aplenty. I just saw a guy rode a horse into a wall and disappear into it. The said guy then proceeded to shoot everyone in the back, and no one is able to get to him. FIX YOUR DAMN GAME, FATSHARK!

Again at the time of writing, I've clocked in six hours into this game. And I encountered three hackers. That translates to one hacker in every two hours. That, to me, is very serious. Note that I played on servers with Anti Cheat on, but I guess that is not working at the moment.

Bottomline: Try the free version, if this game is your cup of tea and you can live with the hackers and cheaters, then buy Kingmaker. Otherwise, forget it.

reviewText: The War of the Roses was a big old 15th Century dynastic squabble between two Plantagenet houses, York and Lancaster, for the throne of England. It ended in a Lancastrian victory, the reconciliation of the two houses, and the creation of House Tudor. Most importantly, it involved a lot of battles filled with armored chaps beating the living daylights out of each other. Fatshark's War of the Roses is all about those fellows, and their bloody clashes. Up to 64 players duke it out amid the pastoral setting of England's verdant countryside, ripped apart by brutal conflict.  It can be a fast-paced slaughterfest one minute, and a methodical, tactical, squad-based multiplayer experience the next.There are fairly limited options in terms of game modes--team deathmatch as well as a conquest-style mode, in which players capture areas, are the only match types. The lack of variety in game modes means the team-versus-team matches can get tiresome. But what War of the Roses lacks in modes, it compensates for in the novelty of gameplay.Getting a kill in War of the Roses is no easy task. It takes a combination of mouse clicks and mouse swipes just to swing your weapon. Blocking works in almost the same vein, so sword fights between two players feels like a real medieval duel. Every move is deliberate, and winning battles comes from skill rather than getting in a few lucky shots. Every attack or bow shot must be calculated and perfectly timed to land, since opposing players can block, dodge, or interrupt your attacks at any time. However, because it is so difficult to land a critical hit, when you actually manage to deliver a crushing blow, it's incredibly satisfying.Those who have played the Battlefield series, will immediately recognize the squad system. When players respawn, they have the option to do so on different points on the map, including on other squad members.When in combat, you have the option to carry a wide variety of weapons, including swords, shields, axes, bows, and poled weapons--like Halberds and spears. Each weapon type differs in effectiveness, and encourages different fighting styles.Your choice of armor plays as much of a part in combat as your weapon. Not only can you unlock visually intimidating armor sets, certain character attributes can be affected, including movement speed and defensive abilities. Some armors can even completely deflect attacks.As you level up from winning matches and getting kills, you'll earn money, which can be used to purchase weapons, armor, character perks, and other bonuses like mounts. The perks break down into offensive, defensive, and squad support perks called Officer perks.Limited though it may be, War of the Roses delivers a grisly, realistic take on third-person medieval combat that hits most of the right notes. More than just a refreshing change of pace for the genre, it captures the raw kinetic essence of the period's turbulent warfare in an exciting way.

So I gave this game a bit more of a chance after writing my first review. And it hasn't changed but so much. While the game can be entertaining most of the time it's cheap and just ****ing horrible quality. You spend half of your time trying to 'charge' up attacks, only to have them not swing correctly (IE-The enemy is too close or your weapon touches a twig) while enemies seem to not be effected by this at all. Direct hits with your blade to enemies sometimes to not register at all either. However every single swing an enemy does to me, even when blocking, seems to deal signifigent damage, often killing me in 1-2 hits while wearing full plate. While when I crit on the face with my two handed axe I hit a max of 28 damage. People use the EXACT same weapon are butchering me in one hit. Is this hacks? I don't know but this game is FULL of hackers as well. Obvious hacking, such as super speeds, aimbots for archers, and more. The lack of servers, especially ones with a ping limit one can stay under, is VERY low. At peak this game may reach 100-200 players across 10 servers or less. Overall the game is unfair and very 'arcade' feeling. Most of the time players are rushing around mindlessly hacking with their insta-gib swords and axes, stuck in a 'charge' animation as they run at you. The feats are pathetic, most of the 'special skills' you get are not even worth mentioning, much less grinding/getting slaughtered for hours on end to unlock.

In short this game is a horrid failure. I played when it was in beta/first released and it was MUCH better than it is now. Obtaining new items is all but impossible. Most cost 100k-500k and you earn less than 2k per match, if you're one of the level 60s with the best gear you can earn upwards of 5k.

But do not fear you can pay stupid amounts of money to get gold. Spending 5$ will get you 500k, but most of the good items are 100k+. The combat is sketchy at best, often people run around like Rambo swinging and butchering with ease but in my experience that isn't something I could do no matter the loud out I chose. Even when attempting to parry+swing+dodge it was all but impossible to land a good hit, it seemed as if even the most perfect hit would be brushed off easily while a grazing hit with a dagger to me could kill me in a single blow. Archery is interesting but a big fail as well. It is EXTREMELY difficult to hit anyone. Trying to watch your arrow/bolt fly through the air is equally frusterating as it's very hard to see.

Is this game worth your 20$? No. Lack of players, VERY difficult to play. Even worse community. Is it a pay to win game? Yes, it -is-. Most of the time it's 1 team completely dominating the other and a lot of clan team stacking. It also does not handle multiple monitors AT ALL. You will have to shut off all your other monitors or you will find yourself clicking off screen almost every swing, even through the game is supposively playing in full screen, it doesn't appear to. The free to play is a gimic, the trial is more discouraging to play than the full game. You get nothing for the trial except the first classes and they are awful. Again, you will be dominated by 'advanced' players that never seem to miss a hit and can't seem to be damage even when hit directly to the face.

Do not buy, do not support.

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: War of the Roses
Original Release: 2013
Genre Tags: MOBA; PvP; Medieval; Slow Paced
My Overall Grade: B+
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): N/A
Multiplayer Aspect: Primary
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Novelty seekers; Multiplayer gamers
REVIEWWar of the Roses is a fun multiplayer PVP experience.  If you like introducing axes to skulls, you will like this game. The combat is slower than most PVP games, but it can make for some intense battles.

Like all PVP games and MOBAs, there is a bit of a learning curve, but it isn't that bad. If you play in the big battles of 32 players then you can quietly learn how to play without being flamed too much.

The combat is slow, and you have to charge and aim your swings (and blocks, if that’s what your into)... so it takes some getting used to. Eventually you learn to compensate for lag too. Some people complain about it, but sometimes the best thing to do is: rapidly swing your most OP weapon towards the enemies’ necks and hope for some decapitations... and just have some fun with it.

Once you do have a firm understanding of how to play it can quickly become quite an addictive and fun experience. There are many flaws inherent in the mechanics of the game, but once you learn how to compensate for them you will be hooked. Little compares to the pleasure of charging into a group of enemy players and quickly taking all of their heads off, then running behind a wall to bandage up while they complain in the chat log. Of course, many times you'll be the one getting decapitated out of nowhere too.

Or, if you want, you can hone your skills as an archer and stand 100 meters away and zip arrows at people trying to perform supportive actions on players (i.e.: revives and executions).

Since there is a free-to-play tier, if you want a taste of MOBA-style medieval combat, then you should give War of the Roses a shot.

reviewText:
War of the Roses is a great game.

The combat has a high skill ceiling but not a steep learning curve, making it equally enjoyable for casual players as well as dedicated hardcore players. If you enjoyed the combat in Mount and Blade you will most likely love the combat in WotR. I personally find it to be a lot more refined.

The graphics are pretty alright, though the game could need some more optimisation.
If you have an older computer or laptop it might not run very smoothly. If that's the case you can still try tweaking the graphics[blurb.boards.net].

The player base is rather small and the remaining servers are often (but not always) run over by morons. Contrary to what the forums might make you believe, the game is not plagued by hackers. There are players using glitches and exploits and other extremely toxic players, but you can usually avoid those.

It is possible to enjoy the game despite these issues and you should definitely try it out! Especially because it's free!

Note: The F2P version is actually the demo, which only" lets you play 4 different classes. For custom classes you need to buy the Kingmaker DLC."

An example: I fear a lightly armoured man with a crudely constructed, wooden pitchfork more than I do a knight, clad in armour, because of one simple fact: the peasant weaving in and out of your swings is actually a player who knows how to exploit the many balance issues of this game! His pitchfork can swing faster than your 2-hand sword (of course), but instead, for some reason, do more ♥♥♥♥ing damage! AND THAT'S RIGHT; HE'S SWINGING HIS PITCHFORK! NOT STABBING! Every time I come across one of those little turds, they kill me so ♥♥♥♥ing hard that I'm throwing up gardening tools at breakfast.

Pitchforks aside, I just feel that WOTR's combat system has been 'balanced' to the point where everything just doesn't make sense anymore. Weapons just arn't dependable, nothing has a realistic crunch, when expected. I feel like I'm being punished for choosing the heavy knight build; Every weapon negates your layers of armour, unless it's a sword, so I'm down as quickly as the next guy. Call me a crying 'noob' but I feel as if I've played enough of this game to be able to voice my opinion.

RABBLE RABBLE RABBLE!

Despite all this, a nice aspect of this game, I have to add, is the level of customisation, and the implimentation of an advanced physics system for weapons.

It's certainly a niche game, but If you're looking for something similar, only a little more... violent and immidiate, try Chivalry.

reviewText:
War of the Roses (WOTR) is a great game, i first found out about it from 'Good Game's' review, the whole team really seemed to like it. After that i was on a mission to get this game i needed to have it, finally after many years... i got it, off ebay for $5.00 for a Steam key. I started playing as soon as i could, it was a bit hard to get used to the controls but that is one of the many things that made it unique! After a lot of practice i started to become a real threat on the battle field this is probably when i started to really get into it, but i was around level 20 when that happened so there was a lot of under dog moments in the time before that. But even when i was getting smashed i was still having fun!

You can play as many as 64 players to a server, this is when it is absolutely crazy! But I did enjoy these crazy servers... I Also really liked the amount of things you can edit in your custom classes, this is where some help from a tutorial can really be useful :D I saved my money to get the heavist armour there was, i thought i would become a HUGE threat when i finally earned the 50,000 coins. I was wrong, just because your heavily armoured doesnt mean you are going to be a great player, the heavy armour makes you incredibly slow. So i would suggest a medium armoured class.

Honestly as much as i loved the game the battle field training was pretty terrible, the AI ( artificial intelligence) did not act anything like a real player would. Plus if you wanted to verse them in a close quarters battle be prepared to get R-A-P-E-D in numbers, even though the AI themselves are very easy to eliminate.

The Coat of Arms is quite precise in this game their are endless combinations, I personally made a very colourful shield/emblem but if you are going for a 'camo' approach, their are appropriate colours to choose from.

The gameplay really is amazing, so far i have played 127 hours of this game and i feel there is much more to master. After all i know a player who is rank 60 and has played over 550 hours, and i run in to him quite often both as team members and as opponents. There could be a bigger selection of game modes though, there are (at the moment) only 3 game modes; Team Death-Match, Conquest and Assault. All thought all these game modes are quite different a bigger selection could really help this game.

I wont get too technical with things like graphics and how well it runs, but it is quite a nice looking game with quite a few unique maps, that really set the Medieval theme great. But the colours on all the maps appear quite dark, but i guess nothing really had to be too bright and that might give it a strange 'cartoony' feeling.

I cant explain how much i love this game, but i would definetely recommend it, I had alot of fun with it and i am glad that there is a War of the Vikings now, that im sure will be just as good :D

10/10 for me :)

reviewText: {*I won't talk about the F2P version as I purchased (the only option when I acquired this game) the so called 'Kingmaker' version and therefore cannot properly realte to it*}\nI bought this game some time ago and was not dissapointed. The melee combat system is similar to that of Mount and Blade: Warband. Each attack is executed from a certain direction (Note: some weapons stab instead of an upward swing) and requires your opponent to use a corresponding block to avoid taking damage. The combat system is supported by the armour and weapon system. Some weapon types are better against different armours, though the skilled player can exploit the joints and gaps in the wearer's protection to deliver damage. For exaple using a blunt weapon tends to be better for bringing down heavily plated knights than bladed arms which bounce off. There are vast amounts of weapons which can be further customised to suit your playing style, as well as many armour types which can be modified (and also painted pretty colours for ridiculous sums of gold). This makes for a very interesting game, with multiple game modes and so called (and unofficial) 'Duel Servers' where you can practice in 1 on 1 matches. Items are either level or XP locked. Gold is earned through playing, dealing damage, killing enemies and helping allies. While gold can be bought it only means you can get a fancier weapon instead of a plainer but very similar/same one, so gameplay isn't affected very much and you can earn it with relative ease through playing. I recommend it greatly, although many people have pointed out the rather steep learning curve. Yes the game is hard and you will always die, but once you get the hang of it, find the arms and armour you prefer, you will see why so many play it. Play for free to see if you like it (you are stuck with the default classes for the first few levels anyway in the paid version, so there isn't any difference) and then decide whether you want to pay or not.

reviewText:
TL:DR Mounted combat is a blast, Weapons are unbalanced, player base is small and full of ♥♥♥♥♥.

This game has remained in my library because it does have a lasting appeal to it, I mean it is a Knight on Knight deathmatch after all, and having played Chivalry as well, I have to give the nod to War of the Roses.

I play this game solely for the mounted combat, galloping into battle on my war steed I couch my lance and direct my tip at an opponents face, as my lance strikes I am rewarded with a shimmering chime sound and an instakill. Very very satisfying. However there are plenty of roles in the game and you'll find one that suits you best, there is a large degree of customization from archer builds to heavily armored polearm builds, rarely are two opponent ever the exact same. The problem here is that within all the customization is a large degree of imbalance. Some of the weapons feel extremely overpowered like the Gallo axe while others like the swords feel somewhat underpowered. There is a reward for reaching the final level in the form of a peasant outfit and pitchfork which essentially 1 shots players, but only if you hit with the sweet spot. I guess I see the joke in this, still it's a little frustrating having to deal with this bit of comedy in every game.

While the game certainly isn't pay to win, you can purchase coin and move yourself ahead a little bit, the really costly items are mainly cosmetic, while there's plenty of easily attainable high quality gear for not much coin. The game comes with several really good preloaded classes as well which you can use to good effect while you save up to create your own custom loadout. Attaining items is as simple as playing the game, earning coin, and then purchasing whatever you want, there is no tedious levelling through weapons aren't interested in to obtain higher level weapons that you are. If you want that golden sword, save up the coin and purchase it straight away.

The community in this game is small, usually only filling one or two servers at any given time, and for the most part are probably the angriest child men you can encounter online. Of course you can always hop on your horse, single them out, and lance them in the face on your next respawn.

As good as all of this sounds, I can't give the game recommendation simply because the developer has abandoned it. There are many issues that need to be resolved in terms of gameplay mechanics and balance that aren't likely to be addressed any time soon. It's a shame because this game has so much potential and could really be expanded. The level design is kinda meh, but it gets the job done, however a little more love to this game could go a long way towards restoring the flagging player base.

This game is so very aggravating. I love it, but at times I find it so unplayable.

The combat is great, the way you can block incoming attacks and power them up to kill others. The bow system is a little off sometimes but gives a realistic feel to the game.

I have also found a couple of the weapons to be way too overpowered in the game. Such as some of the pollaxes that insta-kill very frequently, and crossbows which do the same.
I also found that it is waaaaay too easy to flank or be flanked in this game which really annoys me when I'm playing archer and some heavy armoured guy comes along with his pollaxe and chops my head off. Of course, that is part of the fun in this game (mostly for the armoured guy) but it still is pretty freakin' annoying as you see your allies ahead of you not coming back to help as they don't realise that they have been flanked.

I love this game and will continue to play and rage through it, but I would not recommend it to others.

reviewText:
This is an excellent game, with a steep learning curve. If you are more used to slower-paced games, this game will throw you off. If you are used to games that require little in terms of practice and skill, this game will throw you off. This is not your average multiplayer game, this is something unique and different.

Some claim that the controls are clunky and awkward and, you know what, they are. The point is that it's not something that takes away from the game; rather, it is just another element that you have to learn, adapt to and then master. We are all noobs to begin with and this game makes that painfully clear.

If you're a terribad, you're going to hate this game, because no matter what you do, others will seem to instantly kill you from miles away with a crossbow, mow you down with a horse and lance, crush your face with a hammer coming down on your helmet like the wrath of a severely irked deity... but if you decide to lift yourself above the masses and actually learn the mechanics, learn when to use the dagger, when to use the poleaxe, how the arrows drop off... then you will eventually be rewarded ten-fold, when you snipe that pesky mounted knight right off his horse at 200 yards.

This game rewards skill and, unfortunately for some, skill is not an unlock.

The graphics quality is top-of-the-line and with all settings cranked to the max, it looks as good as any triple-A title on the market. It has some work to do in the optimization/performance department, but those are just details, minor cracks in an otherwise superb presentation. If you don't own a beastly machine, turn shadows off, and your framerate will skyrocket.

Overall, this game is definitely worth the learning curve and money :)

reviewText:
Pre-purchased it.

War of the roses is a fun game for a while, then just around the time you understand the game mechanics perfectly, ex: choice of armor, dictating distance,  weapons, perks, counter classes, how to pick your enemy etc. (not combat mechanics, feints, they're fairly friendly to any MB player) it gets boring and only thing left for you to do is just grind a bit more to get that million dollar sword.(Which is not a game changer, just a skin).

I really like the fact that you can beat any opponent if you're smart enough though even if there are some OP weapons admittedly, it was swords at the beginning, spears later, than swords again and maces later and axes for sometime now  etc. they're not magical wands, if you're a skilled and confident player YES your kills will rise with them, unless someone equally skilled and confident specifically makes a class to counter your setting and haunts you with it.(This is sometimes required for team win)

Community is generally toxic with some saints among them, for some reason beyond my understanding, players with a clantag bullies people tenfold, totally reverse of what it should be but its also rewarding to rescue those oppressed players and teach them some basic feints, pretty much only fun thing to do lately.

Many started criticizing the game from the day one, people whined weapons not doing ANY damage, when they remedied that people again whined that armors are nerfed, hitboxes changed, aim the weak point system tweaked (and rightly so, people with 150 ping couldn't actually put that dagger in eye slits in a dynamic combat even if they had the skill or you couldn't dodge when that dude with 150 ping somehow stabs you in the eye 10 feets away from your back even if you had only 50 pings and yes there will always be ping in internetz) so don't let any reviews fool you of any past memories of grandeur, this game was always what it is NOW, it was just with more people.

Consider this, of all the people who bought it, only %40 ever played it or in other words reached rank 1, and 3 out of 4 that played haven't reached the rank knight (20) (According to achievement rates) which is the rank you start to understand the game IMHO. WoTR can be boring.

It was a still born, neither fully grown nor unique and never had the potential to be a really good game anyways. Best part is graphics.

Buy if you have some friends to play with and means to run your own server (which is a lot of money), pass if you don't feel you need it. If you do buy though and somehow survive the initial shock and get 40s, remember your humble beginnings and don't be an ♥♥♥ in duel servers.

Edit: Thumbs up since its basic version is free.

Edit 2: It is really satisfying when people rush you with no defence in mind because you go with a basic class, only to find that you are not a new player =)  a good ruse worths three man.

TIP : DO NOT EVER get angry over something in this, if you feel you're getting angry just stop playing and watch a movie, return when you're calm and ready to swing some.

reviewText:
This is a game loosely based on Mount&Blade and surpassed it with it's amazing graphics, easy yet challenging game mechanics, game modes and of course it's theme.

There are currently two game modes: Team Deathmatch and Conquest. TDM is about killing every enemy till their points are depleted and Conquest is where you capture certain points on map and defending or pushing further to other points, while killing all the enemies of course.

There's a persistent character progression, meaning you won't start over everytime you start a new game. Everything you do earns you experience points and gold, the more you level up, the more you unlock certain items ready to be bought and added to your collection for which you use the gold you earned. You can create your own custom classes like heavy armoured knights with claymores, light armoured sneaky and fast scouts and mounted cavalries in addition to the ones you get by default.

Proper medieval war with pure PVP fun~ definitely worth it.

reviewText: War of the Roses and Chivalry Medieval Warfare are often directly compared to one another. War of the Roses is third-person action game that revolves around mouse movements to block and attack; and Chivalry is a first-person action game that revolves around button pressing attacks and a single button block. In both games you can play as archers or crossbowman and melee classes. WOTR has cavalry in addition, but the horses are glitchy. In my opinion WOTR has a more precise system of attacking and blocking, as well as a greater emphasis on encumbrance and armor choices compared to Chivalry. Success in both games relies on careful timing and knowing your weapon’s speed and reach. Combat in WOTR has a bit of a learning curve if you haven’t played any of the excellent Mount and Blade series, and some of the weapons could be more balanced. I recommend you try both if you are interested  in the genre, but for me WOTR is the better multiplayer medieval combat game.

The problem is there is like 60-80 people playing (32 ppl servers), most of them join duel servers and they are full of griefers that will constantly murder teammates and revive you while the enemy is waiting to spawnkill you. However if you can find a TDM/Conquest/Assault server they are very fun to play (specially conquest) and you will have no problems there.

Just don't expect to be able to make honorable duels or anything, it's sad there isn't more people playing but I'd still recommend the game because you can try it for free and see if you like it.

reviewText:
This is a great game that no longer has support from the devs but it is still fun to play, it rewards and encourages teamplay overall so it's great to play with friends, it also has great graphics and it performs great with fairly high fps rate. As a free to play you will be able to play any of the premade classes (4) but if you pay the kingmaker DLC you'll be able to customize your soldier (customization is great) to make your own type of soldier, it is very cheap so..

The problem is there is like 60-80 people playing (32 ppl servers), most of them join duel servers and they are full of griefers that will constantly murder teammates and revive you while the enemy is waiting to spawnkill you. However if you can find a TDM/Conquest/Assault server they are very fun to play (specially conquest) and you will have no problems there.

Just don't expect to be able to make honorable duels or anything, it's sad there isn't more people playing but I'd still recommend the game because you can try it for free and see if you like it.

reviewText: One of the most unbalanced games I have ever played. Being based very closely to the mount and blade fighting mechanics and an interesting and unique point in history sounds like a perfect combination for a successful and fun game but quite the opposite happened. Weapon update after weapon update has changed the game from a fairly realistic and accurate medieval fighting game to another try hard game full of unarmoured players running around with unbalanced weapons that do not reflect the rediculous damage they inflict. One of the most powerful weapons is a wooden pitchfork... A better alternative is Chivalry or wait for the new Mount and Blade to be released to get your moneys worth.
